When study reaches its essence and virtue is perfected,
when compassion is deep and wisdom mature—
free of all selfish ambition, of striving for merit or skill—
this is how the virtuous stand unchallenged beneath Heaven and Earth.

Such is the way of the humble and yielding,
of emptying oneself to serve others,
listening to the rise and fall of *qi* and moving with it.
Thus the Elixir forms unseen yet manifest,
unchanging yet transforming,
effortless yet complete—
what difference is there from a master’s skill in guiding others?

In cultivating the human Dao,
if one remains ever at peace,
ever yielding,
desire suppressed without force,
virtue upheld without effort—
this is the virtue of *wu zheng* [non-contention].

With a heart of non-contention,
following principle to act,
responding to circumstances with ease—
it is as if using others’ strength to achieve one’s own purpose,
thus encompassing Heaven and Earth’s transformations without overreaching.

Confucius said:
*"What does Heaven speak? The four seasons move in it,
and all things take life from it."*

The Sage aligns with the Dao’s truth,
upright as the celestial threads and terrestrial measures,
setting the standard for all ages to come.

**Chapter LXIX: The Victorious Through Compassion**

There is a military saying:
*"I dare not be the aggressor while the enemy is passive,
nor advance an inch without retreating a foot."*

This is called:
moving without moving,
pushing without arms,
holding without weapons,
yet standing unconquered.

No greater calamity than underestimating the enemy—
to do so risks losing what is most precious.
Thus, when armies clash,
the compassionate prevail.

Ancient strategists spoke thus:
*"I dare not be the aggressor but must be the guest."*
The aggressor is like a sovereign—
one who issues commands and rules with authority;
the guest is like a minister—
one who obeys the sovereign’s will, as in *"Let others be the host, I the guest."*

Thus, when I am the aggressor,
it is the post-Heaven human heart that takes command,
while the pre-Heaven Dao-heart steps back in submission.
How dare I make the post-Heaven human heart the aggressor,
only to then make it the guest,
relying on it as if it were my very life?

*"I dare not advance an inch without retreating a foot"* means:
when victorious, even an inch gained must be held firm;
when defeated, not even a single step withdrawn may be conceded.
To advance an inch in gain while retreating a foot in loss—
this is to gain little and lose much,
easy to fail, hard to succeed.
In warfare, this is the mark of an incompetent general;
in Dao cultivation, this is the fate of one who achieves nothing.
How dare I?

Only by yielding to others as the aggressor,
submitting myself as the guest,
can I ensure they have openings to exploit,
while I have no vulnerabilities to attack—
thus controlling others without being controlled,
avoiding humiliation.

Advance when opportunity arises,
retreat when danger looms.
In advancing, one must rouse the spirit of boldness;
in retreating, one must not present a vulnerable posture.
Such caution, such vigilance—
it is nothing but always yielding precedence to others,
while placing oneself last.

Thus, when marching an army,
it seems others can move while I cannot;
yet when I press forward with resolve,
brandishing my arms—
it seems others have arms while I have none.
When facing the enemy in battle,
two armies locked in combat—
it seems others can contend while I cannot.

Though drums thunder and flags billow,
though they wield weapons, I do not lack arms.
Yet I advance not lightly, retreat not lightly—
truly knowing that the fate of the state,
the rise or fall of the nation,
rests on this single battle.
How can the enemy be treated with contempt?

Observe the ancients who treated the enemy with caution—
they often succeeded;
those who underestimated the enemy—
they often failed.
As seen in Guan Zhong’s campaign against the Shanrong,
or Zi Yu’s battle at Chengpu.

Moreover, the prosperity or decline of the court
depends on the success or failure of its generals.
If one does not approach matters with utmost prudence,
but instead flaunts their talent or relies on their wit,
boasting *"None surpass me"*—
like Meng Ming’s reckless advance or Gao Gu’s overconfidence—
there has never been one who did not bring ruin to the state,
destroy their own house,
or extinguish their ancestral rites.

The Sage’s greatest treasure is *xin* [trust].
To underestimate the enemy is to betray the sovereign’s trust.

When two armies oppose each other,
two forces clash—
yet one remains weak, yielding,
utterly compassionate and benevolent.
They fear the *sha fa* [killing energy] disrupting Heaven and Earth’s harmony,
and take no joy in military might expanding territory.
Warfare is resorted to only as a last necessity.
Though no weeping for fallen soldiers,
the heart of compassion and sorrow
already permeates the assembled armies,
and the common people are moved to gratitude.

Thus, the virtuous either do not war,
or if they do, they prevail.
Is this not because the heart of sorrow
extends to others,
entering their very beings?

This illustrates the birth of true *yang* energy,
the *qi* flourishing—
only then may the fire be refined.
If one does not patiently await the *yin* [lead] *qi*’s movement,
but instead forces the spirit’s ascent and descent,
advance and retreat in rigid cycles—
there will be no failure to burn the body with wild fire,
to suffer great humiliation.

At the four critical junctures,
one must await the *kan* [water] *qi*’s natural impulse,
lest *li* [fire] usurp dominance—
hence, *"I dare not be the aggressor but must be the guest."*

In the Dao of cultivation,
progress is constant, regression brings disaster.
Like Heaven’s ceaseless motion,
water’s unceasing flow—
only thus does one ascend daily.
If one proceeds intermittently, then halts,
exposed to cold after brief warmth—
this is to advance an inch while retreating a foot,
gaining little, losing much,
and thus never achieving success in this lifetime.

This arises from ignorance of the way of returning to the Root,
restoring the Mandate—
the path of daily practice,
which cannot be seized by clever schemes,
nor attained through contrivance.

chunks.original_text: 惟逆修丹道，顺运自然，学如不学，功而无功，相因而造，顺势而前，无少阻滞，无一把持，若禹之治水，行所无事而已。 倘进火行符，轻于进退，犹行兵者之轻视敌人，未有不火起伤丹，炉残鼎败，以致铅汞一齐飞散者。 噫，纯任自然，敬慎不败，固缉熙于光明； 若妄作聪明，长生之宝必因此后天尸贼，为之戕害无存，又安望其成丹而可大可久哉？ 惟仁慈一片，哀痛十分，而后出之以和平，行之以柔顺，自然所向披靡，战无不胜。 学人慎勿以后天识神为主，而先天元气皆退听焉，庶几其不差矣。 第七十章 被褐怀玉 吾言甚易知，甚易行。 天下莫能知，莫能行。 言有宗，事有君。 夫惟无知，是以不我知。 知我者希，则我贵矣。 是以圣人被揭怀玉。 大道者，人心固有之良，日用常行之事，至近至约，不可顺臾离也。 离则无道，无道则无人，又何言之有？ 况吾之所言，虽累于累万，盈箧盈箱，不可胜数，要皆切于人心，近于日用，无有难知难行者。 顾何天下莫能知莫能行者？ 岂吾言之不易知不易行乎？ 盖言有宗也，即人所不学而知之良知也； 事有君也，即人所不学而能之良能也。 惟言知有宗，则近取诸身，而言皆善言； 事知有君，则默窥其隐，而行皆善行。 夫道若大路然，岂难知难行者哉？ 反身而诚，乐莫大焉。 若不知言之有宗，事之有君，而求诸高远之地，广博之乡，是以玩物丧志，务广而荒，以为形役，性为气累，而本来天德之良，迷慨欤？ 虽然，其知也于我何加？ 其不知也于我何损？ 况我之所以为我，初不因人之知不知也。 知我者希，则我之贵乎我者仍自若也。 是以圣人被至贱之褐，内怀至贵之玉，晦迹山林，藏身岩穴，亦惟顺性命之理，参天地之道，以修其在己，而人之知否从违，概不问焉。 此所以圣者益圣，而愚者愈愚矣。 太上之言，头头是道，字字切身。 即人以言道，即道以言身，易莫易于此矣。 夫何难知难行者哉？ 顾人之昧昧者，良由道在迩而求诸远，事在易而求诸难。 不务真常大道，反求糟粕绪余。 如辞章记诵刑名术数之类，学愈博而心愈荒，事愈繁而性愈劣，无怪乎太上道言。 当时为人心所同，后世为太上所独也。 良由不明言之有宗，事之有君耳。 夫宗者君者，即人身之“中”也。 尧舜授受心传，无非“允执厥中”而已。 后如文之“纯一”，参之"慎独"，柯之“良知”，莫非人身之一“中”也。 此个“中”字，所包甚广。 其在人身，一在守有形之“中”——朱子云：“守中制外”。 夫守中者，回光返照，注意规中。 于脐下一寸三分处，不即不离是。 一在守无形之中——《中庸》云：“喜怒哀乐未发谓之中。 ”罗从彦教李延平：“静中观喜怒哀乐未发气象，此未发时不闻不睹，戒慎恐惧，自然性定神清，方见本来面目。 然后人欲易净，天理复明。 自古圣贤仙佛，皆以此为第一步工夫。 但始须守乎勉然之中，终则纯乎自然之中。 ”三圣人名目各有不同，总不外地“中”字为之宗，为之君。 即如吾教以凝神调息为主，然后回观本窍，心无其心，气无其气，乃得心平气和。 心平则神始凝，气和则息始调。 其要只在心平二字。 心不起波谓之平，能执其中谓之平； 平即在此中也。
chunks.translated_text:
To cultivate the Dao of alchemy in reverse—
to align with Nature’s spontaneous flow—
is to learn as though unlearning,
to labor without labor,
to follow the natural sequence,
to advance with the momentum,
unhindered, unforced—
like Yu taming the floods,
acting where no action is needed.

If one recklessly stokes the fire,
lightly advancing and retreating,
it is like a general underestimating the enemy—
never fails to kindle disaster,
burning the elixir,
shattering the furnace and crucible,
until lead and mercury scatter in ruin.

Ah! To trust Nature purely,
with reverent caution,
is to weave through radiance unbroken.
But if one contrives clever schemes,
the treasure of longevity
will be ravaged by the post-heaven corpse-thief,
destroyed utterly—
how then could one hope for an elixir
both enduring and vast?

Only with boundless compassion,
tenfold sorrow,
does one act with peace,
proceed with gentleness—
then Nature yields without resistance,
and victory is inevitable.

The seeker must not let post-heaven intellect dominate,
but let primordial *qi* retreat and listen.
Only then may one avoid error.

**Chapter Seventy: The Humble Garment, the Precious Jade**
My words are easy to know,
easy to practice.
Yet none under Heaven can know them,
none can practice them.

Words have their root,
affairs have their master.
Only the ignorant fail to recognize me.
Few know me—
thus I am noble.

Therefore, the Sage wears coarse rags,
yet cradles jade within.
He obscures his traces in mountains and caves,
hiding his life in rocks and hollows—
only to follow the nature of life and fate,
harmonize with Heaven and Earth,
cultivate what lies within himself,
while others’ knowledge or ignorance
he does not concern himself with.
Thus the wise grow wiser,
while the foolish grow more foolish.

The Supreme’s words—
every line is Dao,
every character touches the self.
To speak of Dao is to speak of the self,
and to speak of the self is to speak of Dao—
nothing is simpler than this.
Yet what is difficult to know or practice?

It is only that people seek far
when the Dao is near,
demand difficulty
when the matter is easy.
They neglect the true, constant Dao,
and instead pursue dregs and remnants—
like rhetoric, memorization, legalisms, and divination.
The more they learn, the more their minds stray;
the more they do, the more their nature decays.
No wonder the Supreme’s words
were universally understood in his time,
yet only he alone preserved them afterward.
It is because they failed to grasp
that words have a root,
affairs have a master.

This root, this master—
it is the “middle” within the self.
When Yao and Shun passed on the heart-transmission,
it was nothing but *“faithfully holding to the middle.”*
Later, in Confucius’ *“pure unity”*,
Zengzi’s *“solitary vigilance”*,
Wang Yangming’s *“innate knowledge”*—
all point to the self’s *“middle.”*
This *“middle”* encompasses much.

Within the body, it lies in guarding the *xing* (formal) middle—
Zhu Xi said: *“Guard the middle, regulate the outer.”*
To guard the middle is to turn light inward,
focus on the center.
At the point one inch below the navel—
neither clinging nor rejecting.

It also lies in guarding the formless middle—
as the *Zhongyong* says:
*“Before joy, anger, sorrow, or delight arise—this is the middle.”*
Lu Congyan taught Li Yanping:
*“In stillness, observe the state before joy, anger, sorrow, or delight arise—
this unseen, unheard moment,
where caution and awe are natural,
nature settles, the spirit clears,
and the original face appears.
Then human desires grow pure,
Heaven’s principle shines anew.
Since ancient sages, immortals, and Buddhas—
all took this as their first step.
Yet one must first guard the strenuous middle,
and finally attain the effortless middle.”*

Though the Three Teachings name it differently,
they all take *“middle”* as root and master.
Even in my teaching—
to concentrate the spirit, regulate the breath,
then return to observe the original orifice,
letting the heart have no heart,
the *qi* have no *qi*—
only then does the heart grow still,
the breath harmonize.
The key lies in *“heart still.”*
No disturbance in the heart is stillness;
to hold fast to the middle is stillness.
Stillness is within this middle.

chunks.original_text: 心在此中即丹经的玄关一窍。 到得神气相依，玄关之体已立，此为大道根源，金丹本始。 它如进火退符，搬运河车，有为有作，总贵谦和柔顺。 以整以暇，勿助勿忘。 有要归无，无又生有。 至有无不立，方合天然道体。 此即得一而万事毕，吾道“一以贯之”之旨也。 学者如此，太上之轻可解，庶不为旁门左道所感也。 若不知言之有宗，事之有君，未许升堂入室而迷于它往者。 人能知此行此，自然有得于中，无慕乎外，如圣人之被褐怀玉，而融融泄泄不已焉。 第七十一章 知不知上 知不知，上；

The heart here is the *Xuan Guan* orifice of the *Dan Jing*—
when spirit and *qi* become interdependent,
the substance of *Xuan Guan* is already established,
this is the root of the Dao/Way,
the origin of the Golden Elixir.

As for advancing fire and retreating symbols,
shifting and transporting the *He Che*,
all actions and efforts—
they ultimately value humility, harmony,
softness, and compliance.

Be composed and tranquil,
neither aiding nor neglecting.
What is essential returns to the Void,
yet the Void gives rise to the Form.
When Form and Void stand not,
then one aligns with Heaven’s natural Dao/Way.

This is the attainment of unity,
whereby all matters are concluded—
the essence of my teaching’s *“One with a thread that runs through all.”*

If scholars grasp this thus,
the *Taishang*’s subtleties may be understood,
and they shall not be misled by peripheral or heterodox paths.

If one fails to recognize the *宗* of speech,
the *君* of practice,
and does not permit entry into the hall of truth
while wandering in other directions—
the person who knows this and acts accordingly
will naturally find fulfillment within,
no longer coveting the external.
Like the sage who bears coarse robes yet harbors precious virtue,
they radiate effortlessly, ceaselessly.

chunks.original_text: 不知知，病。 夫惟病病，是以不病。 圣人不病，以其病病，是以不病。 睿智所照，自如明镜无尘，止水无波，物来毕照，毫无遁情。 此神明洞彻，自然而知； 因物为缘，如心而出。 非臆度以为明，悬揣以为知者。 其知也由于性光之自照，而不是有前知之明，却能知人所不知。 此上哲之士，非凡人所能及也。 凡人智不能烛理，明不能照物，往往拟议其人之诚伪，逆料乎事之兴衰——幸而偶中，人谓其明如镜，自亦诩其烛如神。 此等揣摩之知，非神灵之了照，乃强不知以为知：虽有所知，其劳心苦虑，其劳心苦虑，病已甚矣，是自作聪明者，自耗神气者也。 夫惟以强知为病，于是病其所病。 而穷理以尽性，修命以俟天。 慧而不用，智而若愚，自然心空似水，性朗如冰，一灵炯炯，照彻三千，又何营回之苦，机巧之劳以为患也哉？ 是以不病。 圣人明烛事机，智周物理。 自有先觉之明，绝无卜度之臆。 故凡人有病，而圣人不病焉者，以其能病所不知，病所不明，而于是一心皈命，五体投忱，尽收罗于玄关一窍之中，久之灵光焕发，烛照无遗，固随在皆宜，亦无往不利也。 以其病病，是以不病。 此言慧照之知，是为上等； 若矫情之知，实为大患。 惟以强知之患为患，是以无患。 圣人之得免于患者，常以此患为患，所以无患。 大旨已明，兹不复赘。
chunks.translated_text:
「Unknown yet knowing, is an ailment.
Only when one recognizes this ailment as an ailment,
does one truly avoid falling ill.

The sage does not fall ill,
because they recognize the ailment of knowing what they do not know,
thus they do not fall ill.

When illuminated by sagacious wisdom,
one’s mind is like a spotless mirror,
still water without ripples—
all things come and are reflected with perfect clarity,
not the slightest trace of evasion.

This is the divine insight, naturally penetrating;
it arises from things as their condition,
emerging like the heart’s own expression.
Not conjectured as clarity,
nor divined as knowledge.

Their knowing stems from the innate luminosity of nature,
not from preordained foresight,
yet they discern what others cannot.

This is the loftiest of sages,
not the reach of common folk.

Common folk cannot fathom principles with their intelligence,
nor illuminate things with their insight—
they often surmise the sincerity or deceit of others,
and guess at the rise or fall of matters—
if by chance they hit upon the truth,
people call their mind clear as a mirror,
and they themselves boast of their piercing discernment like a god.

This kind of divined knowing
is not the divine penetration of insight,
but forcing ignorance into knowledge:
though they claim to know,
their hearts labor and fret,
their hearts labor and fret—
the illness is already severe,
for they deceive themselves as clever,
yet only drain their vital *qi*.

Only when one regards forced knowing as the true illness,
does one then cure the illness they have recognized.

Thus, one exhausts principles to fulfill nature,
refines life to await Heaven’s timing.
Wise yet not using wisdom,
intelligent yet appearing foolish—
naturally, their hearts are empty as water,
their nature bright as ice,
a single luminous spirit,
shining through the *Triśarā* (三千),
why would they suffer from scheming or contrivance?

Therefore, they do not fall ill.

The sage’s understanding of affairs and principles
possesses innate foresight,
utterly devoid of divination or guesswork.
Hence, while common folk fall ill,
the sage does not fall ill—
for they can recognize what they do not know,
what they do not see clearly,
and thus with wholehearted devotion,
they surrender to the mystery of life,
their five senses aligned in truth,
all gathered within the single aperture of the *玄关* (Mysterious Pass).

With time, their luminous spirit blazes forth,
illuminating without remainder—
truly, wherever they are, it is fitting,
and nothing they do is unadvantageous.

Because they recognize the ailment of knowing what they do not know,
they do not fall ill.

This speaks of knowing through insight—
the highest attainment;
if knowing through feigned cleverness,
it is indeed a grave misfortune.

Only when one regards forced knowing as the true misfortune,
does one then have no misfortune.

The sage’s escape from misfortune
lies in always treating this misfortune as misfortune,
thus they have no misfortune.

The grand meaning is now clear;
no need to elaborate further.»

chunks.original_text: 今再将道妙详言之：大凡打坐，必先从离宫修定，做一响而后自考自证，果然空空无物，即明心见性矣。 所以吾尝云：静坐之初，此心悬之太虚，待身心安定，意气和平，然后徐徐以意收摄，回照本宫。 到得了无一物，介于胸间，从此一觉一照，即十方三界，无在而不入我觉照之中。 然而觉性不生、觉性不灭，不过了了自了，如如自如而已。 以此求玄，则水源至清，自可为我结丹之本。 一霎时间，自然性光发现。 何以见之？ 即吾前日所示恍恍惚惚中。 忽然一觉而动，是修道之要始。 而以性摄情，若不先讨出性真本来，突地下水府中求玄，不知既无性矣，何以摄得起情来？ 夫既有虚灵之蓬勃之机。 要知离非属心也，凡凝耳韵、含眼光、戒香味触法，皆是神火主事，故曰属离； 坎非是气，精气所在，即是属坎。 即以神入血中，火热水里，未必即有气机发动——务须左提右挈，摄起海底之波，上入丹田，久久烹炼。 火功既足，忽然天机发动，周身踊跃，从十指以至一身，跳动不止。 身如壁立，意若寒灰。 丹田气暖，此即火之不老不嫩，合中之时。 若非有此效验，尚是微微，不可行火。 若久见此景而不知起火。 气已散矣始行用火，是为药老无用。 学者审之辨之。 然微阳初动，未必即有此盛气，只要心安意适，气息融和，亦可行子午河车。 盖人身有形有质之血，不经火煅，尚是污污浊浊、一团死血。 惟用神火之照，血中自生出一点真气出来。 即佛所云“我于五浊恶世修行而得成道果”是。 又古谓“鬼窠中取宝，黑山下求铅”，是皆不外浊精败血内以神火煅出此一点真气来。 气既动，阳即生，又当知子进阳光，午退阴符，卯酉沐浴诸法，方能采得此真阳，运行流通，内以驱除脏腑之阴私，外以招摄天地灵阳之真气。 久久用功，气质亦变。 此河车一法，有无穷妙义也。 古有言“气明子午抽添”，抽即抽取水府之铅，添即添离宫之汞。 汞即心中灵液，后天中先天。 从色身浊精败血中，以神火煅炼出而成甘露者是铅，即血中之气。 气即古人谓水中之金，此为后天中先天，只可以固凡林，不可以生法身。 此是坎离交而生出来的药物，犹不可以作神丹。 必要以性摄情，以性归性，性情和合，同煅于坤炉之中，忽地真阳发动，此为乾坤交而结丹。 始可炼神丹为真仙子。 总之，修炼别无它法，只是一个河车运转。 初关河犹须勉强； 中关河车，天人合发； 到得上关河车，纯乎自然之天，不失其时而已。 至于卯酉沐浴诸法，不过恐初学人心烦火起，行工不得不然。 若到纯熟，不须法矣。 总在学人神而明之可也。

「Now let us further elucidate the subtleties of the **Dao/Way**:

In general, when practicing seated meditation (*dàzuò*), one must first cultivate **定** (meditative stability) within the **離宮** (Palace of Rebirth), achieving a single resonance before self-reflection and self-verification. If indeed it is found to be utterly empty and devoid of substance, then the mind is clarified and **性** (true nature) is seen.

Thus, I have often said: At the outset of still-sitting, this mind hangs suspended in the **太虚** (Great Emptiness). Only when the body and mind are settled, and **意** (intent) and **氣** (qi) are harmonized, does one gradually gather and return the mind to reflect upon its own **本宫** (Root Palace). When one arrives at the state of absolute emptiness, with nothing between the chest, then from this moment of awakening and illumination, the **十方三界** (Ten Directions and Three Realms) are nowhere that does not enter one’s awakened illumination.

Yet, **awakening-nature** neither arises nor perishes—it merely is, **了了自了** (clearly self-illuminating), **如如自如** (suchness self-so). Through this, one seeks the **玄** (Mysterious), and the source water becomes supremely pure, naturally becoming the foundation for my **結丹** (alchemical elixir).

In a flash, the **性光** (nature-light) spontaneously manifests. How does one perceive this? It is within the **恍恍惚惚** (dimly vague) state I previously demonstrated. Suddenly, upon awakening, movement occurs—this is the essential beginning of cultivating the Dao/Way. Yet, to gather **情** (passions) with **性** (nature), if one does not first uncover the true nature of **性**, and abruptly descends into the **水府** (Abode of Water) to seek the Mysterious, how can one possibly gather **情** when there is no **性**?

For indeed, there exists the **虛靈** (void-spirit) and **蓬勃** (vigorous) **機** (mechanism). Know that **離** is not of the mind—when one concentrates the ears on sound, the eyes on light, and restrains the senses from scent, taste, and touch, these are all affairs of the **神火** (spiritual fire), hence it is called **屬離** (attributed to Rebirth). **坎** is not **氣** (qi)—wherever **精氣** (essence-qi) resides, it is **屬坎** (attributed to Abyss). Even if one directs the spirit into the blood, and the fire into the water, the **氣機** (qi-mechanism) may not yet be activated—one must firmly grasp and pull, stirring the waves from the **海底** (ocean’s depths), ascending them into the **丹田** (Elixir Field). After prolonged refining, when the **火功** (fire cultivation) is sufficient, suddenly the **天機** (heavenly mechanism) is activated, causing the entire body to surge with vitality, from the ten fingers to the whole body, ceaselessly trembling. The body stands like a wall, the intent as cold as ashes. When the **丹田**’s **氣** grows warm, this is the **火** (fire) at its **不老不嫩** (neither too strong nor too weak) peak of coalescence. If this effect is not observed, one remains merely **微微** (slightly faint), and fire cannot be practiced. If one sees this state for long yet fails to ignite the fire, only then does one apply fire to the already dissipated **氣**—this is the **藥老無用** (elixir past its prime, useless).

Students must carefully discern this.

However, when the **微陽** (subtle yang) first stirs, it may not immediately produce such vigorous **氣**—one need only settle the mind and ease the intent, harmonizing the breath, and may proceed with the **子午河車** (Child-Midday Elixir Circulation). For indeed, the human body possesses **形質** (form-substance) blood, which remains **污污渾渾** (filthy and turbid), a mass of stagnant blood, unless refined by the **神火** (spiritual fire). Only through the illumination of the spiritual fire does a single point of **真氣** (true qi) emerge from the blood.

This is what the **Buddha** spoke of: *“In this fivefold turbid and evil world, I cultivated and attained the fruit of the Dao/Way.”*

Again, the ancients said: *“To take treasure from the ghost’s nest, to seek lead beneath the black mountain”*—these are all but the **真氣** (true qi) extracted from turbid essence and decayed blood through the refining of spiritual fire. Once the **氣** (qi) moves, **陽** (yang) arises—one must then know that **子** (Child) advances the yang-light, while **午** (Midday) retreats the **陰符** (yin-symbol). The **卯酉沐浴** (Tiger-Dog Bathing) methods, when practiced, allow one to gather this **真陽** (true yang), making it circulate and flow internally to dispel the **陰私** (hidden yin) within the **臟腑** (zang-fu organs), and externally to attract the **天地靈陽** (heaven-earth’s numinous yang). With prolonged practice, the **氣質** (qi-nature) also transforms.

This method of **河車** (Elixir Circulation) holds boundless profundity. The ancients spoke of *“gas brightens, Child-Midday draws and adds”*—drawing refers to extracting **鉛** (lead) from the Abode of Water, and adding refers to supplementing **汞** (mercury) from the Palace of Rebirth. **汞** is the **靈液** (numinous fluid) within the heart, the **後天** (post-heaven) containing the **先天** (pre-heaven). From the **色身** (form-body), **渾精敗血** (turbid essence and decayed blood), the **神火** (spiritual fire) refines and produces this **甘露** (ambrosia)—this is **鉛** (lead), the **氣** (qi) within the blood. **氣** (Qi) is what the ancients called the **金** (gold) in water, a **先天** (pre-heaven) within **後天** (post-heaven); it can only solidify the **凡林** (mundane body), not generate the **法身** (Dharma-body).

This is the medicine produced by the **坎離交** (Abyss-Rebirth interaction), yet still insufficient for **神丹** (spiritual elixir). One must then gather **情** (passions) with **性** (nature), and return **性** to **性** (nature to nature), harmonizing **性情** (nature-passions) to refine together in the **坤爐** (Kun Furnace). Suddenly, the **真陽** (true yang) emerges, forming the **乾坤交** (Heaven-Earth interaction) to congeal the elixir—only then can one refine **神丹** (spiritual elixir) into the **真仙子** (true immortal embryo).

In summary, there is no other method of cultivation—only the **河車** (Elixir Circulation) turning. At the **初關** (First Pass), one must exert effort; at the **中關** (Middle Pass), the **河車** (Elixir Circulation) is activated by both **天人** (heaven and humanity); when one reaches the **上關** (Upper Pass), the **河車** (Elixir Circulation) is purely natural, without fail.

As for the **卯酉沐浴** (Tiger-Dog Bathing) methods, these are merely precautions for beginners lest their minds be troubled and the fire be stirred prematurely, causing their work to falter. When one reaches pure mastery, no methods are needed. It all depends on the student’s ability to **神而明之** (manifest and clarify the spirit).」

chunks.original_text: 第七十二章 民不畏威 民不畏威，大威至矣。 无狭其所居，无厌其所生。 夫惟不厌，是以不厌。 是以圣人自知不自见，自爱不自贵。 故去彼取此。 所谓威者，纲常名教之大，天理所最难犯者。 使知慎独于衾影，畏天威于隐微，自然天锡纯嘏，眉寿无疆。 《诗》曰：“畏天之威，于时保之。 ”若天威俨在咫尺，而戒慎弗懔旦明，致令伦常澌灭，礼义消亡，则天良无存，天罚不贷，而凶灾不免，性命难全。 是民不畏威，大威至矣。 若是者，皆由不知知仁为安宅，旷安宅而弗居； 义以生气，舍生气而自丧也。 呜呼！ 彼民不幸，未生太古之世，以德威为畏，德明为怀，故愚昧外愆，天显罔顾，而旱干水溢，疫疠灾荒，种种祸患兴矣。 惟在上者导以天下之广居，使游心于太和之宇，无狭隘为居，而日蹈于危亡也； 引以浩然之正气，使直养于清虚之天，无厌弃其生，而自罹于断绝也。 夫惟自爱其生之理，自保其天之良，而不稍厌斁，即《诗》云：“敬天之怒，无敢戏豫； 敬天之渝，无敢驰驱也”。 天监厥德，俾尔炽而昌，俾尔寿而臧，实有与天地同为悠久者焉，是以不厌。 非圣人其孰能之？ 古帝王恭己无为，懋昭大德，日就月将，洗心涤虑，精参造化之妙，洞晰本来之天，惟自知之耳。 至若德业文章，外之所着，圣人绝不以之表见于人。 且朝乾夕惕，重道守身，一息不肯离乎仁，天下无有加于己。 其自爱为何如？ 它如名位声华，人之所尊重者，圣人绝不以之足贵。 虽圣人自知自爱之端，亦凡人共知共爱之端——特凡人知之而必见之，爱之而必贵之； 圣人自知不自见，自爱不自贵。 其慎幽独，而不致炫耀于人； 重保养，而不敢矜尚于世。 岂凡人所可同日语乎？ 夫亦曰去欲取理，尽人合天，以至超凡人圣，绝类离群，而成亿万年不朽之神者，皆由此自知广居之安，自爱长生之乐，一于此不二于彼，而民自迁善而不知为之耳。 舍此乌能若是哉？ 此言无狭所居，其所居者必大。 无厌所生，其所生者必长。 虽然，用工之际，元神识神，不可不知。 夫人受气之初，从父母媾精时，结成一点黍珠，此时絪絪缊缊，只有一团太和之气，并无一点知识。 然而至神至妙，极奇尽变，作出天下无穷事业出来，都由此一点含灵之气之神，从无知无识而有知有识，从无作无为而有作有为，莫非由此而始。 此时天人一理，物我同源，体用兼赅，显微无间，故曰元神。 此是天所赋畀的。 到得血肉之躯既成，十月胎圆，呱地一声，婴儿落生，此时识神始具。 夫元神者先天之元气，天地人物一样，都藏于太虚中。 一到人身，则隐伏于人身虚无窟子之内。 此是天所赋者。 修行人欲修成大道，夫岂可着空着色以求之哉？ 惟有一无所知，一无所有，扫却一切尘氛，而个中消息自现，灵妙自生。 至若识神，乃人身精灵之鬼，万劫轮回种子，必要五官具备，百骸育成，将降生落地时，然后精灵之魂魄，方有依附。 古人谓后天识神，因有形魄而生者也。 此元神之大分别处也。 但有生之后，元识两种神，交合一处——有时元神用事，识神退听，则后天之意气虽动，要皆由仁义礼智，而发为喜怒哀乐，识神亦化为元神者此也； 有时识神用事，元神隐没不见，虽仁义礼智之见端，亦皆变为私恩、私爱、私憎、私嫌，元神亦化为识神者此也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Seventy-Two: The People Do Not Fear Authority**

The people do not fear authority—then true authority has arrived.

Do not confine their dwelling, do not exhaust their life.
Only because they are not exhausted, they are not exhausted.
Thus, the Sage knows himself but does not display himself,
loves himself but does not exalt himself.
Hence, he discards that and embraces this.

What is called authority is the great framework of norms and teachings,
the most sacred principle of Heaven, which must not be violated.
If one knows to be cautious in solitude, even in bed and shadow,
and fears Heaven’s authority in hidden deeds,
then naturally Heaven bestows pure blessings,
and longevity extends without bound.

The *Classic of Poetry* says:
*"Fear Heaven’s authority,
and in its time, you shall be preserved."*

If Heaven’s authority looms close at hand,
yet one does not guard against it with vigilance and clarity,
causing moral order to collapse,
and propriety and righteousness to vanish—
then conscience perishes,
Heaven’s punishment is unrelenting,
and calamity cannot be avoided,
while life itself is imperiled.

This is why it is said:
*The people do not fear authority—then true authority has arrived.*

Yet this arises because they do not know
to take *ren* (benevolence) as their secure dwelling,
but abandon it without inhabiting it;
to take *qi* (vital breath) as their life,
but discard it and bring ruin upon themselves.

Alas! Those people, unfortunate,
born not in the ancient age,
fear authority as *de* (virtue/power) and *wei* (awe),
revere clarity as *ming* (illumination) and *huai* (embrace)—
thus, in ignorance and transgression,
Heaven’s signs are ignored,
and droughts, floods, plagues, and famines arise in succession.

Only the rulers above should guide them
to dwell in the boundless realm of the world,
so that their minds may roam in the harmonious expanse of *Taihe*,
not confining themselves in narrowness,
nor daily courting ruin;
should lead them to draw upon the vast *he* (noble) *qi*,
so that they may nourish themselves in the pure and empty Heaven,
not exhausting their life,
nor inviting self-destruction.

Only by cherishing the principle of preserving life,
safeguarding Heaven’s innate goodness,
and never growing weary or decaying—
then the *Classic of Poetry* says:
*"Revere Heaven’s wrath,
and dare not trifle with it;
revere Heaven’s decrees,
and dare not rush blindly."*

Heaven observes their virtue,
granting them prosperity and flourishing,
granting them longevity and preservation—
truly, they share in the eternal duration of Heaven and Earth.
Thus, they are not exhausted.

Who but the Sage can achieve this?

The ancient emperors, reverent and non-actional,
exalted in great virtue,
day by day, month by month,
cleansing their hearts and purifying their thoughts,
penetrating the mysteries of creation,
discerning the original Heaven—
only knew themselves.

As for deeds, writings, and outward achievements,
the Sage utterly rejects them as means of self-display.

Moreover, he remains ever-vigilant, morning and evening,
cherishing the Dao and guarding his essence,
never straying from *ren* for a single breath—
none can surpass him in this.

His self-love is such that
even what others hold in highest esteem—
names, positions, fame, and glory—
the Sage does not deem them worthy of pride.

Though the Sage’s own self-awareness and self-love
are what all people commonly know and cherish—
yet common people, knowing them, must display them,
loving them, must exalt them;
while the Sage knows himself but does not display himself,
loves himself but does not exalt himself.

He is cautious in solitude, yet does not flaunt himself before others;
he values preservation, yet does not boast before the world.
How can common people compare?

It is said: abandon desire, fulfill humanity, align with Heaven,
thus transcending humanity to become Sage,
separating from the common to become divine,
and attaining immortality of countless eons—
all this arises from
self-awareness of dwelling in boundless ease,
self-love of eternal joy,
uniting in this and not dividing from it,
so that the people naturally turn to goodness without knowing why.

Apart from this, how could it be so?

This speaks of not confining one’s dwelling—
then one’s dwelling must be vast.
Not exhausting one’s life—
then one’s life must endure.

Yet in the practice, the original spirit and the recognizing spirit
must be understood.

When a person first receives *qi*,
from the moment of parents’ union,
a single grain of millet forms—
at this time, indistinct and indistinct,
only a cluster of *Taihe* qi,
with no trace of knowledge.

Yet it is supremely divine, supremely wondrous,
exhausting all transformations,
giving rise to boundless affairs in the world—
all from this single spark of sentient qi,
from non-knowing to knowing,
from non-action to action,
all beginning here.

At this stage, Heaven and humanity share one principle,
things and self share one source,
substance and function are complete,
manifest and subtle are unbroken—
thus, it is called the *original spirit*.

This is what Heaven bestows.

When the flesh-and-blood form is complete,
ten months in the womb fulfilled,
a cry, and the infant is born—
then the *recognizing spirit* begins to take shape.

The *original spirit* is the primordial *qi* of Heaven and Earth,
shared by all things, hidden within the void.
Once it enters the human body,
it dwells concealed in the empty cavities within.

This is Heaven’s gift.
Those who cultivate the Great Dao
cannot seek it through emptiness or form.

Only by being utterly without knowledge,
utterly without possession,
sweeping away all dust and haze,
does the inner truth reveal itself,
and divine mystery arise.

As for the *recognizing spirit*,
it is the ghostly essence of the human body,
the seed of countless rebirths,
requiring the completion of the five senses
and the hundred bones—
only when descending into birth and taking form
does the soul have a place to depend upon.

The ancients called this the *postnatal recognizing spirit*,
for it arises from having form and body.

This is the great distinction between the *original spirit*.

Yet after birth, the two spirits—original and recognizing—
merge into one.
Sometimes the *original spirit* acts,
while the *recognizing spirit* retreats in obedience—
though the intentions of the postnatal self may stir,
they must emerge through *ren, yi, li, zhi*,
manifesting as joy, anger, sorrow, or delight,
and the *recognizing spirit* transforms into the *original spirit*.

Sometimes the *recognizing spirit* dominates,
while the *original spirit* hides unseen—
though the traces of *ren, yi, li, zhi* appear,
they all become private affection, private love,
private hatred, private resentment,
and the *original spirit* transforms into the *recognizing spirit*.

chunks.original_text: 总之，为口耳一身起见，皆是识神。 一到识神用事，焉有光明正大，可以对天地、质鬼神的事业出来。 惟混混沌沌中，神焉一感而动，此时天理纯全，毫不挟后天识见，如能稳立脚根，端然行去，即纯乎天理，而无一毫人欲之私。 吾故教人于无知无觉时，寻玄关一窍，良以此时与天地一体，与虚空一致。 能从此把握行将去，则天地之生生，不难自我而为生生； 虚空之变化，不难自我而神变化。 此时一觉，诚为天地人之根源。 修士不从此下手，又从何处以为仙圣之阶哉？ 要之，无思无虑而出者，元神也； 有作为见解、自色身而出者，识神也。 元神无形，识神有迹。 一自虚无中来，一从色身中出，二者大不相侔。 既明得元神生于虚无，识神生于色身，我于是正本清源，务令内外三宝闭塞，不许一知一见从有形有象、有思有虑而出。 如此操持，如此涵养，久久尸魄之灵皆化为清净元神，八万四千毫毛亦转为护法灵神。 所谓化识为元，转阴成阳者此也。 此在人实力于虚无一边，不要为色身起见着想得矣。 第七十三章 不召自来 勇于敢则杀，勇于不敢则话。 此两者或利或害。 天之所恶，孰知其故？ 是以圣人犹难之。 天之道，不争而善胜，不言而善应，不召而自来，坦然而善谋。 天网恢恢，疏而不漏。 《诗》曰：“维天之命，于穆不已。 ”人盗天地之气以为丹，即盗于穆不已之天命。 此命在天即清虚一气，在人即太和一气。 惟由平旦直养，直至浩然，充塞乎两大，即返本复命，上下与天地同流矣。 养之维何？ 一在于死妄心——死妄心贵于刚，刚刚不屈于物，而令正气常伸； 一在于生真心——生真心贵于柔，柔则能悦诸心，而令浩气常凝。 此两者一往无前、奋其果敢之力者，死机也。 逡巡不前，甘为懦弱之材者，生气也。 勇于敢则杀，勇于敢则活，此进为退基，负为胜本。 《易》曰：“日中则仄，月圆则蚀。 ”天地盈虚与时偕行，或利或害，往往与世相反。 故人之所喜，天之所恶也。 且夫天亦何所恶哉？ 好生者彼苍之心，有时不用生而用杀； 尚德者上帝之意，有时不以德而以刑。 此盖生中寓杀，杀中有生，其意深微，有非人所能测度者。 天之所恶，孰能知其故耶？ 是以修道之圣人，知福为祸基，柔为刚体，酌经权而用其中，忘利钝而守其正，不与凡人争利害，惟于一己辨从违。 至于降灾赐福，惠吉替凶，虽圣人犹难测其微，况下焉者乎？ 夫圣之道，亦天之道也。 圣人纯任自然，而进退升降，至运转于一身之中。 天道无为自然，而生长收藏，常流行于太虚之表，所以不与万物争强。 而修短频临，究无一夫之能傲，是不争而善胜矣。 不与下民言理，而祸福所及，卒无一地之或逃，是不言而善应矣。 虽其中或迟或速、或重或轻，暗中自有权衡，有不由人谋者在。 故曰：“不召而自来，坦然而善谋。 ”任他才智过人，奸巧绝世，而肺肝洞见，虽张皇掩饰，有何益乎？ “天网恢恢，疏而不漏”，洵不诬也。 遏欲贵果，不果则人心放纵，人欲缠绵，故勇于敢者杀———所以杀，人心也。 存理贵柔，不柔即凡气暴躁，元气动摇，故勇于不敢则活——所以活，元神也。 然死心所以活者相济。 人心易死，道心易生，顾其中有天道焉。

Thus, all that arises from the body and senses—mouth and ears—is the *recognizing spirit*.
When the *recognizing spirit* dominates,
where is the radiant clarity, the upright and just,
capable of aligning with Heaven and Earth,
questioning the spirits and deities?

Only in the boundless chaos,
does the spirit stir at a single sensation—
here, Heavenly Principle is pure and complete,
untainted by postnatal *recognizing spirit* and perception.
If one can firmly stand in this state,
proceeding with steadfast resolve,
then one acts purely in accordance with Heavenly Principle,
without the slightest trace of human desire’s private influence.

Thus, I instruct people:
when in a state of no knowing, no awareness,
to seek the *play of the mysterious* at the Pass.
For at this moment,
one is unified with Heaven and Earth,
harmonious with the void and space.

If one can grasp this from the outset,
then Heaven and Earth’s eternal generation
will not be difficult to manifest within oneself;
the void’s transformations
will not be difficult to embody as spirit.
At this moment, when one awakens,
truly, it is the root of Heaven, Earth, and humankind.

If practitioners do not begin here,
then from where shall they ascend to the stages of Immortal and Sage?

In essence,
that which emerges without thought or deliberation is the *original spirit*;
that which arises with purpose, perception, and from the colored body is the *recognizing spirit*.
The *original spirit* is formless,
the *recognizing spirit* leaves traces.
One comes from emptiness,
the other issues from the colored body—
these two are vastly dissimilar.

Having understood that the *original spirit* is born from emptiness,
and the *recognizing spirit* from the colored body,
I thus rectify the root and clear the source,
striving to close the inner and outer *Three Treasures*,
not permitting a single thought or perception
to arise from form, image, thought, or deliberation.

Through such cultivation and such nurturing,
over time, even the vital essence of the corpse-like body
will transmute into pure and serene *original spirit*,
and the eighty-four thousand hairs
will become protective spirits of the *Dharma*.

This is called
*transforming the recognizing spirit into the original spirit*,
*converting the yin into yang*—
this is achieved by firmly grounding oneself in emptiness,
not allowing the colored body’s perceptions to entangle the mind.

---

**Chapter 73: Not Summoning Yet It Comes**
*"The bold are slain; the bold in restraint are saved."*
These two paths bring either gain or harm.
What Heaven detests, who can fathom its reason?
Thus, even the Sage finds it difficult.

The Dao of Heaven
is victorious without strife,
responds without speaking,
comes without being summoned,
and yet its schemes are ever-good.
The Heavenly net is vast and sweeping,
coursed yet never failing.

The *Odes* say:
*"The Heavenly mandate—
mysterious and ceaseless."*

He who steals the *qi* of Heaven and Earth to make elixir,
steals from the mysterious and ceaseless Heavenly mandate.

This mandate, in Heaven, is the pure and serene *qi*;
in humankind, it is the *Great Harmony qi*.
Only through nurturing from dawn’s first light,
until the *boundless and overflowing qi* fills the two great voids,
does one return to the root and recover the mandate,
flowing above and below with Heaven and Earth alike.

What is this nurturing?
First, in the *death of false thoughts*—
the *death of false thoughts* values firmness;
firmness does not bend to external things,
thus allowing *upright qi* to persist.
Second, in the *life of true Principle*—
the *life of true Principle* values gentleness;
gentleness pleases all hearts,
thus allowing *boundless qi* to solidify.

These two—
one pressing forward without hesitation, resolute in daring,
is the *death-mind*;
one hesitating and faltering, willingly yielding to weakness,
is the *life-qi*.

The bold in daring are slain;
the bold in restraint are saved—
this is the foundation of advance and retreat,
the root of failure and triumph.
The *Book of Changes* says:
*"At high noon, the sun declines;
when the moon is full, it wanes."*

Heaven and Earth’s fullness and emptiness
follow the rhythms of time,
sometimes bringing gain, sometimes harm,
often contrary to the world’s expectations.

Thus, what humankind rejoices in,
Heaven may detest.

But what does Heaven truly detest?
The *Heavenly Sovereign’s* love for life—
sometimes it does not foster life but brings death;
the *Highest Sovereign’s* reverence for *virtue*—
sometimes it does not reward *virtue* but metes out punishment.

This is life within death,
death within life—
its meaning profound and subtle,
beyond what humankind can measure.

What Heaven detests, who can know its reason?
Thus, the Sage who cultivates the Dao
knows that *blessing* is the foundation of *calamity*,
that *gentleness* is the essence of *firmness*,
and balances *experience* and *authority* in their use,
forgetting gain and dulling ambition,
to uphold what is right,
not contending with the common for profit or harm,
but discerning within oneself what aligns or opposes.

As for disasters and blessings,
bestowing fortune or misfortune,
even the Sage struggles to perceive their subtleties,
let alone those below them.

For the Dao of the Sage
is also the Dao of Heaven.
The Sage follows nature purely,
while advance, retreat, ascent, and descent
turn within the body’s transformations.
Heaven’s Dao is effortless and natural,
while life, growth, contraction, and storage
flow ceaselessly through the *Great Void’s* expanse—
thus it does not contend with all things for strength,
yet its influence is ever-present,
so that even the most skilled cannot resist it—
this is victory without strife.

It does not speak of Principle to the common folk,
yet its disasters and blessings reach everywhere,
no place escaping—
this is response without speaking.

Though its effects may vary in swiftness or weight,
in darkness, there is an unseen balance,
a measure beyond mortal scheming.
Thus it is said:
*"Not summoned yet it comes,
spontaneous yet its schemes are ever-good."*

Even if one’s talent and cunning surpass others,
and one’s insight pierces the depths,
though one may fluster and conceal—
what use is it?
*"The Heavenly net is vast and sweeping,
coursed yet never failing."*
Truly, this is not false.

To suppress desire is to value daring;
without daring, the human heart runs wild,
human desire clings endlessly—
thus the bold in daring are slain—
this is the *death of the recognizing spirit*.
To preserve Principle is to value gentleness;
without gentleness, ordinary *qi* becomes violent,
the *original spirit* unsettled—
thus the bold in restraint are saved—
this is the *life of the original spirit*.

Yet the *death of the false heart* aids the *life of the true*—
the human heart is easily extinguished,
the Dao-heart easily kindled.
But within, there is the Dao of Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 天有好恶，刑与德并施，生与杀共用。 人或知之矣，而具生机于杀机之中，伏活机于死机之内，世人未易窥测焉。 天之所恶，孰知其故哉？ 圣人心同天地，知恶之正所以好之——且非恶无以成好。 此中循环妙用，虽圣人犹难知之。 然而圣人之道，亦即天之道也。 天不与凡民争是非而发育万物，无有不荷其煦妪而悖而驰之者； 不与凡民言感孚而阴阳迭运，无有不相为默契而悖而驰之者。 盖天人一道，寂然不动，感而遂通，化何神也！ 物我同源，廓然大公，物来则应，措何当欤？ 至人以无思无虑之真，默运神功于生杀之舍，暗袭天机于造化之宫，入水府，造金乡，踵希夷，绝视听，杀者生之，生者杀之，初不知其何以相胜相应，如子母夫妇，不召自来，不谋自合。 如此其感孚之捷而神耶？ 至灾祥予夺，祸福贞淫，天网恢恢，疏而不漏，诚无有逃而脱之者，以虚空即道，道即天，不能逃虚空，即不能逃天网。 人不违道即不违天，天休不于以滋至哉？ 第七十四章 民不畏死 民不畏死，奈何以死惧之？ 若使民常畏死而为奇者，吾得执而杀之。 孰敢？ 常有司杀者杀。 夫代司杀者杀，是谓代大匠斫。 夫代大匠斫者，希有不伤其手矣。 古之治天下者，必因乎民情之所易动，而预为之防。 不因人君之喜忧，惟视民情之好恶，顺其势而利导之，所以其教不肃而成，其政不烦而治。 若民之灭纪败伦，干犯名分，而毫无畏死之心，我以五刑之设，悬于象魏，读之月吉，是徒劳其设施，而无补于国计民生也，岂不枉费心力哉？ 惟因民之贪生而惧死，有敢为奸邪奇诡者，吾乃从而杀之，正所谓制一以警百，少惩而多诚。 斯民自父训其子，兄勉其弟，不敢职为乱阶，以自戕生而就死。 然杀之虽在其上，而所以杀之，亦视乎其人。 惟至仁杀至不仁，则民自杀之而不恕，死之而亦甘。 孟子谓“惟天吏则可以杀之”是。 夫天吏乃可杀人，是常有司杀人者矣。 若非天吏而以暴诛暴，是以乱治乱，不惟民乱益甚，而且代司杀者杀，犹之代工匠而运斤成风，挥斧斫轮，其能神乎技而妙于成哉？ 历观古今匠士，其身不能大匠，而代大匠斫者，奚有不伤其手耶？ 彼民不幸，不获生于有道之世，是以寇贼奸宄，殊无忌惮。 又不幸不遇司杀之人，则启沃无从，反还何自？ 以致薄者愈薄，而厚者亦薄矣。 不亦大可伤乎！
chunks.translated_text:
Heaven has its affections and aversions,
punishment and virtue applied in tandem,
life and death employed together.
Though some may grasp this,
they fail to perceive how life thrives within death’s mechanism,
or how vitality lurks within mortality’s grasp—
the world struggles to fathom this.

Who can fathom Heaven’s aversions?
The Sage aligns their heart with Heaven and Earth,
knowing that what Heaven abhors is precisely what it cherishes—
for without aversion, there could be no true affection.
This cyclical marvel, even the Sage finds hard to grasp.
Yet the Sage’s Way is none other than Heaven’s Way.

Heaven does not contend with the common folk over right and wrong,
yet nurtures all things—none escape its warmth and care,
nor transgress and stray.
It does not speak of trust and response,
yet yin and yang alternate in perfect accord—
none fail to harmonize, nor transgress and stray.
Truly, Heaven and humanity share the same Way:
still and unmoving, yet responsive and unified—
how wondrous its transformation!
All things and I share the same source,
boundless and impartial—
when things come, they are met with fitting response—
how could action be otherwise?

The Perfect One, with their unthinking, unburdened truth,
silently works divine power in the realm of life and death,
stealthily seizing Heaven’s intent within the palace of creation.
They enter the Watery Realm, forge the Golden Country,
follow the Venerable One, severing sight and sound.
To them, death is life, life is death—
they know not how victory and response intertwine,
like parent and child, husband and wife—
unsummoned yet arriving, unplanned yet harmonized.
Is this not the swiftest trust and response, the most divine?

As for calamities and blessings, rewards and punishments,
fortune and misfortune, the Heavenly net is vast and sweeping—
none escape its threads.
For emptiness is the Dao, the Dao is Heaven—
one cannot escape emptiness, nor the Heavenly net.
To not defy the Dao is to not defy Heaven—
how could Heaven’s rest be otherwise?

**Chapter Seventy-Four: The People Do Not Fear Death**
If the people do not fear death,
how can you frighten them with death?
If I could make the people always fear death as something extraordinary,
I could seize and execute them—who would dare?
But there are always those charged with execution who carry it out.
To substitute for those who execute is like substituting for the Master Carpenter.
He who substitutes for the Master Carpenter—
how few escape uninjured?

Ancient rulers who governed the world
must follow what easily moves the people’s emotions
and preemptively guard against it.
They do not follow the ruler’s joys and sorrows,
but observe the people’s affections and aversions,
guiding them by their natural inclinations for their benefit—
thus their teachings succeed without rigidity,
their governance thrives without excess.

If the people destroy propriety and family bonds,
transgressing norms and rank,
yet show no fear of death,
then my establishment of the Five Punishments,
displayed on the ceremonial grounds,
declared on auspicious days—
this is but wasted effort,
offering no benefit to the state or its people.
Is this not a waste of effort?

Only by leveraging the people’s love of life and fear of death
can I punish those who dare commit wickedness and deceit—
this is to strike one to warn a hundred,
to deter few while inspiring many to sincerity.
Thus the people themselves—
fathers admonish their sons,
elders encourage their younger brothers—
none dare act as a stepping-stone to chaos,
risking life to court death.

Yet execution rests with those above,
but the reason for killing lies in the nature of the offender.
Only the supremely virtuous may execute the supremely unvirtuous—
then the people themselves execute without resentment,
and die with acceptance.

Mencius said, *“Only Heaven’s officers may be executed.”*
If Heaven’s officers may be killed,
then there are always those charged with execution.
But if it is not Heaven’s officer and yet the violent are punished with violence,
this is to govern disorder with disorder—
not only does the people’s chaos worsen,
but substituting for those who execute is like
a substitute craftsman wielding the axe to shape the wheel—
how could they rival the Master’s skill and perfection?

Examining artisans past and present,
none can match the Master’s craft—
yet those who substitute for the Master Carpenter,
how many escape unharmed?
Alas, the people are unfortunate—
not born in an age of virtue,
so bandits and criminals act without restraint.
Even more unfortunate, they encounter no executioners—
no guidance or awakening is possible,
and so the thin grow thinner,
while even the virtuous become thin.
Is this not deeply lamentable?

chunks.original_text: 以畏死喻慎独。 人惟慎独功深，则天人辨白，理欲分明。 欲寡过而未能，思免愆而不得——于此兢兢业业，汲汲皇皇，省察其几微，克制其伪妄，不难欲净理纯，立见本来面目。 若于不睹不闻之地，平日无操存涵养之功，而于欲动情胜时，思拔除恶孽，顿见性天，势必不除恶而恶多，愈洗心而心乱。 太上曰：“民不畏死，奈何以死惧之。 ”理势乃相因也，惟能慎机于幽独，既有以知欲念之非，乃克遏欲于临时，庶可以还天心之正。 一念扫除，一念清净，自不萌芽再生于其际。 此民常畏死，而为奇者，吾得执而杀之，孰敢颠越不恭，败坏伦常。 盖以有道驱无道，犹人君抚绥万姓，统驭群黎，以至仁杀至不仁，以大义诛不义，自然没有顺而存者安，近者悦而远者来，不致有倒戈相向，反戟为攻，而为仇为害也。 学者欲去伪存诚，反本归根，其必杜之以渐，守之以恒，庶一窍通而窍窍都灵，元神安而神听命。 所谓“人能常清净，天地悉皆归”； 又曰人能一正其神，则诸邪自不敢犯。 此与司杀者从而杀之不怨、死之亦安，同一自然之道、希有之效焉。 第七十五章 贤于贵生 民之饥，以其上食税之多，是以饥。 民之难治，以其上之有为，是以难治。 民之轻死，以其上求生之厚，是以轻死。 夫惟无以生为者，是贤于贵生。 从来民为邦本，食为民天。 国无民则国谁与辅？ 民无食则民何以生？ 是在为人上者，有以开田辟土，浚其源于未食之先； 制礼谨变，节其流于已食之后； 而复省耕以补不足，省敛以助不给——民自家给人足，而无庚癸之呼，饥馑之叹矣。 即干旱不一，饥馑荐臻，而仓箱有蓄，自凶荒无忧。 无如世之人主，骄淫不靖，糜费日繁：或珍奇玩好以为娱，或琼楼瑶室纵其欲，往往仓廪一空，而用度不减。 正供尚欠，又加以重征：始而添租益税，犹胥畏乎民岩； 继则暴敛横征，并不顾乎天命。 声色是尚，奢华并臻。 取万民之胸膏，纵一己之淫荡。 即至国帑空虚，而诛求不稍贷焉。 夫天地生财，只有此数。 若此苛求不已，取民无度。 即大有频书，丰年履庆，而欲其不饥也得乎？ 郅隆之世，衣衣食食，宅宅田田，各亲其亲，各长其长。 其君子无礼义之访，而自居仁由义； 其小人无忠厚之好，而自乐业安居。 盖上行为为治，下以无为自化。 俗不期淳而淳，风不求古而自古。 懿铄休哉，何其盛欤？ 迨其后科条愈设，而风谷愈偷； 法令频彰，而盗贼弥炽。 其在暴虐之君无论矣，甚至英睿之王，奋发有为，励精图治，政愈繁而伪愈多，法愈严而奸愈出。 是岂气术之难回，天心之莫易乎？ 抑以不知穷源固本，而徒求之于末流？ 不惟无补无民生，反有累于世道焉。 盖民心本无事也，而上以政令扰之； 民情本无欲也，而上以章程乱之。 朝廷多一政令，百姓多一奸欺； 朝廷多一章程，百姓多一奇巧。 无怪乎世道之大非，民情之日变，而愈治愈难也。 惟在上者端拱垂裳，斯在下者自安分守命。 上与下相安于无为之天，不亦乐乎！ 且乃致轻内，其劳心也日繁，其损精也愈甚。 而神气因之消亡，身命因之殒灭，愈贪生愈速死矣。 是以求生之厚，反轻死也。 惟不以生为荣，且不以求生为重，衣食随缘自奉，用度与物无争，则心安而身泰，自性复而命延，永享无疆之福也。

「To liken caution in solitude to the fear of death,
one must know that if a person is diligent in self-cultivation,
then the distinction between Heaven and humanity becomes clear,
and the division between principle and desire is manifest.

When desires are few but fail to be fully restrained,
and one strives to avoid transgressions yet cannot—
here, with constant vigilance and earnest striving,
reflecting on even the subtlest inclinations,
and curbing the false and deceptive,
it is not difficult to achieve purity of principle and clarity of mind,
and instantly reveal the original face of things.

But in places where no one observes or hears,
and where there is no daily practice of moral cultivation or self-restraint,
when desires surge and emotions overwhelm,
thinking to uproot evil and eradicate sin,
and suddenly perceiving the true nature—
the result must be that evil is not uprooted but multiplies,
and the more one strives to purify the heart, the more it becomes disordered.

The *Tàishàng* says: *"The people do not fear death—how can you frighten them with death?"*
The principle and its effect are thus interdependent—
only by being cautious in solitude can one truly know the falsity of desires.
Then, when desires arise in the moment,
one can restrain them with resolve,
and thus return to the rectitude of Heaven’s heart.

When one thought is swept away,
and another remains pure,
evil will not spontaneously regenerate at that juncture.

As for the people who habitually fear death,
those who dare to transgress or disrespect
and corrupt the norms of propriety,
I shall seize and execute them—who will dare?
For the Daoist drives out the non-Daoist,
just as a benevolent ruler soothes the masses,
governs the common folk,
and with utmost compassion restrains the most uncompassionate,
with supreme justice punishes the unjust—
naturally, none who submit will remain secure,
while the near ones are content and the distant ones come,
preventing the rise of rebellions or counterattacks,
nor turning into enemies or causing harm.

A scholar who seeks to discard falsehood and preserve sincerity,
to return to the root and reflect on the origin,
must do so gradually and steadfastly,
until one insight opens and all faculties become responsive,
and the original spirit is at peace, obeying the commands of the mind.

As it is said, *"If a person can remain constantly pure,
then all of Heaven and Earth shall be his domain."*
And again: *"If a person can rectify his spirit,
then all evils will not dare to approach."*

This is akin to the executioner’s punishment—
no resentment when he kills,
no unease when one dies—
the same natural Dao, the same rare effect.

**Chapter 75: The Sage Values Life Less Than Nobility**
The people’s hunger arises from their rulers’ excessive tax consumption,
thus they hunger.
The people’s difficulty in governance stems from their rulers’ interference,
thus they are hard to govern.
The people’s indifference to death comes from their rulers’ extravagant pursuit of life,
thus they hold life lightly.

Only those who do not prioritize life itself
are truly wiser than those who revere it.

From ancient times, the people have been the foundation of the state,
and food is their Heaven.
A state without people—who shall support it?
People without food—how shall they live?

Thus, for those in power,
there must be diligence in opening fields and cultivating land,
deepening the roots before the people have eaten;
establishing rites and moderating changes,
regulating the flow after the people have eaten;
and further, reducing labor to make up for shortages,
and curtailing expenditures to aid those in need—
so the people themselves provide ample sustenance,
and there are no laments of scarcity or hunger.
Even if drought strikes and famine follows,
if the granaries are stocked,
worries of calamity vanish.

But in the world today,
rulers indulge in arrogance and licentiousness,
their wasteful spending ever increasing:
some seek rare delights and curiosities for amusement,
others build palaces of jade and pavilions of precious stones to satisfy their desires.
Often, the granaries are emptied,
yet their expenditures do not diminish.
Even basic provisions are lacking,
and they impose heavier burdens:
first, they add extra taxes and levies,
still fearing the people’s resistance;
then, they seize ruthlessly and demand excessively,
even disregarding Heaven’s will.
Their love of music and beauty is paramount,
luxury and extravagance reach their height.
They drain the vital essence of the people,
while indulging their own debauchery.
When the state’s treasury is exhausted,
yet their demands relentlessly continue—
how can one expect no hunger,
even in years of abundant harvests and frequent blessings?

In the age of *Zhuó Lóng*,
clothing was for all, food for all,
homes for all, fields for all—
each cherished their kin,
each honored their elders.
The virtuous did not need to be taught rites and propriety,
for they naturally resided in benevolence and followed righteousness;
the common folk did not require lessons in loyalty and sincerity,
for they found contentment in their work and peace in their homes.
The ruler’s conduct itself was the governance,
while the people transformed themselves effortlessly.
Customs were pure without intent,
manners ancient without seeking them—
how flourishing and harmonious was that era!

But later,
as laws and regulations multiplied,
customs grew ever more corrupt;
the more decrees were proclaimed,
the more thieves and bandits thrived.
Even in tyrannical rulers, this is expected,
but even wise and enlightened kings,
who strive with vigor and exert themselves in governance,
find that the more complex their policies become,
the more falsehoods arise,
and the stricter their laws,
the more deceitful schemes emerge.
Is this not because the *qi* and its influence are hard to reverse,
nor because Heaven’s will is unchangeable?
Or is it because they fail to grasp the root and foundation,
and instead seek remedies in superficial measures?
Not only does this fail to benefit the people,
it also burdens the Way of the world.

The people’s hearts are inherently without strife,
yet their rulers disturb them with policies;
the people’s emotions are naturally without desire,
yet their rulers disrupt them with rigid codes.
For every additional decree from the court,
the common folk devise a hundred more deceits;
for every new regulation,
the people invent a hundred more clever evasions.
No wonder the world’s ways are so corrupt,
the people’s hearts shift daily,
and governance becomes ever more difficult.

Only when the ruler sits upright and relaxed,
does the people below naturally settle into order and obedience.
Above and below live in harmony under the natural governance of Heaven—
is this not joyful?

Moreover,
the more one seeks to preserve life,
the heavier the burden on the mind grows,
and the greater the depletion of vital *qi*.
As the spirit and *qi* dissipate,
life itself is extinguished—
the more one clings to life, the sooner death comes.
Thus, the more extravagant the pursuit of life,
the more lightly death is held.

Only those who do not regard life as an honor,
nor place excessive weight on preserving it,
who take food and clothing as they come,
and do not compete with others in their expenditures,
will find peace of mind and bodily ease,
their true nature restored and life prolonged,
and enjoy eternal, boundless blessings.»

chunks.original_text: 养其太和，自邀天眷，较之以为为贵者，不贤于万万倍耶？ 神喻君也，民喻精也。 顺行常道，以神为主，而精随之以行。 故神一驰，精即泄。 精之消耗，由神之飞扬——喻民之饥，由上食税之多。 其事不同，其理则一。 心为身主，天君泰然，百体从令； 天君不宁，则一身精气耗矣，岂但下田倾倒已哉？ 是以神仙有返还之术，以气为主，而神听其号令——犹君从人欲、顺民情，庶气足神完，而民安国泰。 此以上奉下，以上之有余，补下之不足者。 即以一人事天下，不以天下事一人之意。 丹道虽曰有为，亦要从无为而有为，有为仍还无为，方是先天之神气，可以入圣超凡。 若一概有为，则神不静而气亦弱，势必炼而气不聚，愈炼而气愈纷。 惟因其势而利导之，顺其时而措施之，修身治民，皆作如是观。 若恐货财不足，身命难存，于是竭精疲神，希图养后天之命，日夜焦劳，寤寐辗转，神气之消灭者多矣。 又况惟天之命，非人所求。 君恐求生者无以幸生，且促其生于死地。 惟不贵后天有限之生，隐以持先天无穷之命，庶性全而命固，身形亦足贵矣。 第七十六章 柔弱处上 人之全也柔弱，其死也坚强。 万物草木之生也柔脆，其死也枯槁。 故坚强者死之徒，柔弱者生之徒。 是以兵强则不胜，木强则拱。 强大处下，柔弱处上。 人禀阳和之气则生，阴寒之气则死。 一当阳和气聚，则四体柔顺，一身苏绵，而生机不息矣； 一当阴寒气结，则肌肤燥熯，皮毛槁脱，而死气将临矣。 试观釜甑之间，蒸蒸浮浮，则阳气氤氤，物融而化； 到寒冻时候，物冷而坚。 又观天地春夏之交，阳气炽而万物畅茂，无不发荣滋长； 迨至秋冬之会，阴气盛而万物飘零，无不枯槁。 人物一源，无分彼此。 是知天下万事万物，无不以坚强为死之徒，柔弱为生之徒也。 譬诸用兵，往往强者取败，弱者取胜——如子玉过刚败绩，伯比赢师胜随是也。 其故何耶？ 盖以强者衰之渐，弱者兴之几，宜其不胜矣。 再观诸木，木至坚也，阴气盛而阳气衰，宜其大止拱把，而无由滋育焉。 夫强大者生气尽，而死气临，诚物之至下者也； 柔弱者阴气消而阳气盛，乃物之至上者也。 人奈何不自弱而自强，不处下而处上哉？ 修炼之道，最重玄关一窍，是为天地人物生生之始气。 此气至柔而刚，至弱而强，且刚柔强弱俱无所见。 惟恍惚杳冥中，忽焉阴里含阳，杀里喻生，似有似无，若虚若实，此真无声无臭，上天之载之始机也。 人能盗此虚无元始之气，则先天生生之本已得，而位证天仙不难矣。 即盗得玄关始气，以为金丹之宝，然二候采药，亦当专气致柔，如稚子骨柔体弱而握固，始得初气以为丹本。 四候行火，又要知一身苏软如绵，美快无比，方是先天絪缊蓬勃之机，冲和活泼之象。 有此阳气，可炼仙丹。 再于退符之候，归炉封固，入鼎烹调，犹当绵绵密密 ，了了如如，无怠无荒，如醉如痴，神懒于思，口懒于言，所谓“天下春云如我懒，谁知我更懒于春”。 如此之柔之弱，方是先天阳气，可以长存而不敝。 总之，十月怀胎，三年乳哺，九年面壁，无非先天柔弱之气，为之丹成而仙就耳。 修士当寻此柔脆之气，始不空烧空炼，枉劳精神也。 第七十七章 为而不恃

Nurturing the *Taihe* within,
one naturally invites Heaven’s favor—
how much more excellent than those who prize artificial contrivance
by a millionfold measure?

The spirit is the sovereign; the people, the vital *qi*.
Following the constant Dao,
taking the spirit as master,
while the *qi* moves in accordance.

Thus, when the spirit strays,
the *qi* immediately dissipates.
The depletion of *qi*
arises from the spirit’s unrest—
just as the people’s hunger
comes from excessive taxation above.
Though their forms differ,
their principle is one.

The heart is sovereign over the body;
when the Heavenly Lord is serene,
all limbs obey his command.
But if the Heavenly Lord is disturbed,
then the body’s *qi* is exhausted—
how much more so when the fields are laid waste?

Thus, the Dao of immortals lies in returning to the original,
taking *qi* as master,
while the spirit follows its command—
just as a ruler yields to desires and follows the people’s will,
so that *qi* is full and the spirit complete,
and the people at peace, the state flourishing.

This is the way of the superior serving the inferior,
of the above having surplus to supplement the below’s lack—
treating the world as oneself, not oneself as the world.

Though the Dao of the Elixir speaks of *action*,
it must arise from *non-action* to *action*,
and *action* return to *non-action*—
only then does one grasp the primordial *qi* of Heaven,
able to transcend humanity and attain sainthood.

If one relies solely on contrivance,
the spirit will not be still, nor the *qi* strong.
Necessarily, refining will fail to gather *qi*,
the more one refines, the more scattered the *qi* becomes.

Only by following its natural course and guiding it appropriately,
adapting measures to the time,
whether cultivating oneself or governing the people,
must one hold this view.

If one fears poverty and death,
exhausting the spirit and *qi* in pursuit of a finite, later-born life,
night and day in torment,
sleep and wakefulness in distress—
how much the spirit and *qi* are wasted!

Moreover, life is Heaven’s decree,
not something one can claim.
The ruler fears that those who cling to life
will only hasten their own demise.
Only by not valuing this limited, later-born life,
and instead preserving the boundless, primordial essence,
can one safeguard the true nature and secure life—
then the body itself becomes precious.

---
**Chapter 76: The Soft and Weak Hold High Ground**
The complete person is soft and weak in life,
but rigid and strong in death.
Grasses and trees, in life, are tender and fragile,
but in death, withered and brittle.
Thus, the rigid and strong are companions of death,
while the soft and weak are companions of life.

Therefore, the strong in arms do not conquer,
the rigid in wood cannot bend.
The strong and great must yield to the lowly,
while the soft and weak ascend above.

When a person receives the warm *yang* *qi*, they live;
when they receive the cold *yin* *qi*, they die.
When the warm *yang* *qi* gathers,
the four limbs grow supple,
the body soft and pliant,
and life’s vitality never ceases.
But when cold *yin* *qi* congeals,
the flesh dries and withers,
the skin and fur crack and fall away,
and death’s *qi* approaches.

Observe the pot and steamer—
when steaming, the *yang* *qi* rises thickly,
and things dissolve and transform.
But in freezing weather,
things grow cold and hard.

Observe the earth in spring and summer—
when *yang* *qi* is fierce, all things flourish and grow,
none failing to thrive.
But when autumn and winter meet,
*yin* *qi* prevails, and all things wither and fall.

Human and thing share the same source,
with no distinction between them.
Thus, all things under Heaven,
whether great or small,
are companions of death in their rigidity,
and companions of life in their softness.

Consider warfare—
often the strong are defeated,
while the weak prevail—
as when Ziyu’s overrigidity led to defeat,
and Bibi’s yielding won victory over Chu.
Why is this?
Because the strong decline gradually,
while the weak hold the seeds of rise—
thus, they cannot prevail.

Observe the trees—
wood is most rigid,
yet when *yin* *qi* is strong and *yang* *qi* weak,
it is bound and broken,
with no way to nourish itself.

The strong and great exhaust their life *qi*,
while death’s *qi* approaches—
truly, the lowest of things.
The soft and weak dissolve *yin* and strengthen *yang*,
becoming the highest of things.

How can one not embrace weakness and reject strength,
not yield to the lowly and ascend above?

The Dao of cultivation most emphasizes the *Xuan Guan* orifice,
the origin of Heaven, earth, and all things’ life-giving *qi*.
This *qi* is supremely soft yet firm,
supremely weak yet strong—
yet neither soft nor hard, neither weak nor strong is seen.
In the hazy, distant void,
suddenly, *yin* contains *yang*,
death gives birth to life—
seemingly present, yet absent;
seemingly real, yet empty—
this is the true, scentless, soundless,
Heaven’s initial mechanism.

If one can steal this primordial, void-beginning *qi*,
then the origin of Heaven’s life-giving essence is obtained,
and attaining immortality is no difficulty.

Even if one steals the *Xuan Guan* origin-*qi*
as the Elixir’s treasure,
yet in the four seasons of gathering medicine,
one must focus *qi* to achieve softness—
like an infant, bones soft and body weak yet grasp firm—
only then does one obtain the initial *qi* as the Elixir’s foundation.

In the four seasons of refining fire,
one must know the body’s softness, like cotton,
unmatched in comfort—
this is the primordial, unspun, blooming vitality,
the symbol of harmonious, lively *qi*.
With this *yang* *qi*, one can refine the Elixir.

At the stage of returning to the cauldron and sealing,
still one must be softly persistent,
clearly aware,
neither slack nor reckless—
like drunkenness, like madness,
the spirit lazy in thought,
the mouth lazy in speech—
as the saying goes:
*"Under Heaven, spring clouds are as lazy as I—
who knows I am even lazier than spring?"*

Only such softness and weakness
preserve the primordial *yang* *qi*,
able to endure without decay.

In summary,
ten months in the womb,
three years at the breast,
nine years of seclusion—
all are the primordial soft and weak *qi*,
which completes the Elixir and achieves immortality.

The cultivator must seek this tender *qi*,
lest they burn and refine in vain,
wasting their spirit and *qi*.

**Chapter 78: Receiving the Realm’s Filth**

The Way of Heaven—is it not like drawing a bow?
The high it depresses, the low it raises;
The excessive it diminishes, the deficient it supplements.
The Way of Heaven supplements the deficient and diminishes the excessive,
But the Way of Man is otherwise—
It diminishes the deficient to serve the excessive.
Who then can serve the world with their excess?
Only the Sage of the Way.

Thus the Sage acts without relying,
Achieves without dwelling—
Does he not wish to be seen as virtuous?
The Way of Heaven flows and nourishes all things,
Through ceaseless interplay of yin and yang,
Forward and backward, alternating without end—
Great, central, and perfectly just,
Neither partial nor biased.
Hence, when yin reaches its extreme, yang arises;
When yang reaches its extreme, yin arises.
If yin is excessive and yang is weak,
Then yin is suppressed and yang is bolstered;
If yang is excessive and yin is weak,
Then yang is suppressed and yin is bolstered.
Ebb and flow, swelling and waning,
Move in harmony with the seasons,
Thus life and transformation unfold,
Achieving effortless spontaneity,
An eternal, unexhausted Heaven.
What differs from one who draws a bow?
With bow held firm and intent upright,
The body straight, the front and rear arms aligned—
The high is depressed, the low is raised,
The excessive is diminished, the deficient is supplemented.
Then, following the natural motion,
The arrow finds its mark without fail.
How unlike the Way of Heaven’s natural course—
Taking the people’s fat and marrow,
Filling their bellies,
Yet often diminishing the deficient to serve the excessive.
Who then can use the ruler’s excess
To supplement the people’s deficiency?
Only the Sage of the Way,
Who follows the Way of Heaven and aligns with human nature,
Diminishing where diminished, supplementing where supplemented,
So that the common folk have no cause for grievance.
Though acting for oneself,
It is still in accordance with the Way of Heaven—
Never boasting of one’s deeds;
Though achieving, it is only sincerity—
Never claiming credit for one’s work.
Such a person,
Truly aligns with Heaven’s effortless transformation,
Not forcing the natural course,
Not desiring to be seen in action.
The glory of creation shines upon all—
Is it not because the virtuous do not seek to be seen as virtuous?
This is why Heaven has no limits,
And only the Sage unites Heaven and Earth.

At birth, man is pure yin and pure yang,
Perfectly balanced, neither superior nor inferior.
Thus, day by day, month by month,
His bones grow soft, his body weak yet thrives.
After life begins,
Fire dwells above, water below—
Water and fire do not intermingle,
So yin is always excessive, yang always deficient.
When yang-water is scorched by yin-fire,
The human heart grows ever more restless,
Worldly passions burn brighter,
While the true heart fades daily,
True *qi* dwindles away—
The vital principle of life is lost.
If the excessive yin-fire supplements the deficient yang-water,
And after supplementing yang-water,
Still restrains the excessive yin-fire—
Like one drawing a bow,
Diminishing the excessive, supplementing the deficient—
Then yin and yang are restored.
This is all the natural movement of water and fire,
The natural interplay of yin and yang,
And Heaven knows not of their doing.
The Way of Man is burdened by action,
The Way of Heaven is honored by non-action.
What else is cultivation but
Returning post-Heaven yin and yang
To pre-Heaven yin and yang,
Flowing endlessly in effortless spontaneity?

**Chapter 79: Receiving the Realm’s Filth**
The world has nothing softer or weaker than water,
Yet nothing surpasses it in overcoming the hard and strong.
There is no substitute for it.
Thus, the weak overcomes the strong,
The soft overcomes the hard—
All know this, yet none can practice it.
Therefore the Sage says:
*"To bear the realm’s filth is to be its sovereign.
To bear the realm’s misfortunes is to be its king."*
This is contrary speech.

The *Taishang* chapter before spoke of the soft and weak as the source of life,
And the hard and strong as the source of death.
Thus, the soft and weak occupy the high,
The hard and strong occupy the low—
It is clear that the utmost softness is the utmost strength,
The utmost weakness is the utmost power.
One must practice day and night,
Ever choosing the soft and weak as beneficial to all,
Always dwelling in the low and filthy without aversion.
Though but a drop, men may scorn it.
Though but a ladleful, men may despise it.
Yet when it accumulates into a deep pool,
Gathers into an ocean,
It becomes vast and boundless—
It can bear ships and also capsize them;
It can nurture life and also destroy it.
Not only does the world have no equal,
But even those skilled at overcoming the hard and strong
Cannot break what is firm, cannot shatter what is strong,
And none can resist it.
Thus, the world’s utmost softness
Can govern the world’s utmost hardness;
The world’s utmost weakness
Can drive the world’s utmost strength.
Water, water!
How soft and weak it is,
Yet how hard and strong it becomes!

Moreover, there is no task easier than attacking water,
Yet the hard and strong cannot conquer it.
Why then do men not embrace softness and reject hardness,
Not choose weakness and reject strength?
Is it not because, though they know the soft overcomes the hard,
The weak overcomes the strong,
Their innate virtue, once stirred,
Is immediately stained by desire and habit,
So they bristle with arrogance,
Unwilling to rest in softness and weakness.
Thus, cleverness grows while principle fades,
Partiality thrives while true nature is lost.
The result is that the moral heart departs,
The human heart arises;
Foreign *qi* flourishes, true *qi* wanes.
Life’s foundation is gone, its vitality extinguished—
How could one then hope for ceaseless generation?
The Sage says, *"To bear the realm’s filth is to be its sovereign,"*
As did King Tang: *"If I have guilt, it lies not with the myriad lands;
If the myriad lands have guilt, it lies with me."*

chunks.original_text: 退步即为进步，所以受天命于无穷也。 “受国之不祥，是为天下王。 ”如武王曰：“受克予，非朕文考有罪，惟予小子无良。 ”自后即为自前，所以荷天休于勿替也。 岂同后世之卧薪尝胆，蒙垢纳污者，所得而拟议哉？ 此真常不易之理，万古不磨之经，是为天下正言，而圣人则反求诸己，又何尝以此苛求于人哉？ 水喻一阳初动，真精始生。 其机至弱，其势至柔。 而渐采渐结，日益月增，以至于浩然之气，至大至刚，塞乎两大，统乎万物，而无坚不入，无强不破者焉。 《悟真》云：“白虎首经至宝，华池神水真经。 上善若水利源深，不比寻常药品。 ”顾气之柔弱，有似于水：至柔而寓自刚，至弱而兼至强，实有擎天顶地，捧日举月，呼风唤雨，驱雷掣电之威，是天下之坚强者。 虽曰浩气，其实真精。 须以至柔至弱之神养之，而以无为为为，无功为功，庶几得矣。 其曰“受国之垢，是为社稷主； 受国之不祥，是为天下王”者何？ 即古人反躬自责，朕实不德，民有何辜之意也。 学者求之于人，何苦反修诸身之为得耶？ 第七十九章 常与人善人 和大怨必有余怨，安可以为善？ 是以圣人执左契，而不责于人。 故有德司契，无德司彻。 天道无亲，常与善人。 修身之道，惟善为宝。 为善之道，自治为先。 盖道在内而不在外； 修在己而不在人。 惟事事内观，时时返照，过则改之，善则加勉。 庶明善诚身，永为天地之肖子，圣贤之完人，而不至有所缺矣。 足见为善者只问己之修省，不问人之从违。 如责人而不自责，观外而不观内，虽一时小忿，积而至于大怨，纵能十分解散，而不至于成仇。 然内无返躬自责之道，惩忿窒欲之功，虽能解之于外，而不能释之于隐微，安能清净无尘，潇洒自乐，而复乎本然自善之天地哉？ 故和大怨必有余怨，安可以为善？ 惟圣人持身接物，处己待人，一以修己为主，而人之是非好恶，概不计较。 譬如合同契约，分左右而执之，永以为凭，明尔无我虞，我无尔诈之意。 圣人执德如执左契，只修诸己不责诸人，此所以与天地同其大也。 是谓“有德者司契”。 无德之人，重外轻内，常以察察为明，而人之恩怨必较，此为“无德者司彻”。 夫“司彻”者，以考过为事，全不自省而民弗从，何如司契者责己重，责人轻，而人无不相孚以信！ 可知责人者轻己，己之善难完； 责己者轻人，己之善克复也。 人底于善，而天心眷顾，自亿万年而不杇。 《书》曰，“皇天无亲，惟德是辅”，即太上“天道无亲，常与善人”之谓欤？ 圣人之学，惟洗心退藏于密。 以外之善好丑，是非从违，一概不计。 所以汰虑沉思，凝神默照，以至于心明性见，欲净理纯，上与天合德，历万古而不磨。 其功始于守中，其成由于胎息，内亦知之乎？ 古人言胎息，学人莫是看作外息外气，的是凡息停时，那丹田中真阴真阳，元神元气，融会一团，混成一气，氤氤氲氲，蓬蓬勃勃，若开若阖，若有若无。 视不见，听不闻，想象之而有迹，恍惚之而有形者，此殆人生之始气。 心得之而有体，性得之而有用，人非此气不能生。 欲成上品之仙，亦离不得此气为之主。 古云人生之始，因理有气，因气有形，此天地生人之顺道也。

「To retreat is to advance—
Thus one receives the Heavenly Mandate from the boundless.

*"To bear the realm’s ill fortune is to rule the world."*
As did King Wu: *"I have conquered you, not because my father, King Wen, was guilty,
But because I, your humble subject, was unvirtuous."*

To later is to be prior—
Thus one bears Heaven’s grace without replacement.

How could it compare with later ages’ *bed of thorns and tasting gall*,
Or those who endure filth and accept slander?
This is the eternal, unchanging principle,
An immutable scripture through the ages—
The true words of the world,
Yet the Sage only turns inward to seek within oneself,
Never demanding this of others.

Water is a metaphor for the initial movement of *yang*—
The true essence begins to form.
Its mechanism is most weak,
Its force most soft.
Yet gradually it gathers and solidifies,
Day by day, month by month,
Until it becomes the vast and boundless *qi*,
Most great and most hard,
Filling the two extremes,
Unifying all things—
Yet nothing is too firm for it not to penetrate,
Nothing is too strong for it not to overcome.

*The Awakening to Truth* says:
*"The White Tiger’s first scripture is a priceless treasure,
The Godly Pool’s true scripture of essence.
The highest excellence is like water, benefiting its source deeply—
Not comparable to ordinary elixirs."*

Observe how *qi*’s softness and weakness resemble water:
Most soft yet containing inherent hardness,
Most weak yet encompassing utmost strength—
Truly possessing the power to prop up the heavens and support the earth,
To cradle the sun and raise the moon,
To summon wind and call rain,
To drive thunder and wield lightning.
This is the world’s ultimate firmness and strength.

Though called *vast qi*,
Its essence is the true elixir.
One must nurture it with utmost softness and weakness,
And act with *wuwei* as the method,
Achieve *wuwei* as the function—
Only then may one attain it.

What is meant by *"To bear the realm’s filth is to be its sovereign,
To bear the realm’s ill fortune is to rule the world"*?
It is the ancient practice of self-reproach,
Of declaring, *"Truly, I am unvirtuous—
What wrong have the people committed?"*

If scholars seek virtue in others,
Why not first cultivate it within oneself?

**Chapter Seventy-Nine: Always Do Good to Others**
*"To reconcile great grievances will surely leave lingering grievances—
How then can it be called virtue?"*
Thus the Sage holds the left contract,
Yet does not blame others.
Therefore, the virtuous govern contracts,
The unvirtuous govern disputes.
Heaven’s Dao has no favorites,
Yet always favors the virtuous.
The way of cultivating oneself,
Is to cherish virtue as its treasure.
The way of doing virtue,
Is to first govern oneself.
For the Dao resides within,
Not without;
Cultivation lies in oneself,
Not in others.
Only by observing inwardly at all times,
And reflecting back upon oneself at every moment—
To correct faults and reinforce virtues—
May one truly clarify virtue within oneself,
And forever be the worthy child of Heaven and Earth,
The complete Sage and Saint,
Without any deficiency.

It is clear that those who do virtue
Only question their own cultivation and reflection,
Not others’ compliance or defiance.
If one blames others yet does not blame oneself,
Observes only outward appearances and not inward truth—
Though one may momentarily disperse anger,
And not reach the point of enmity,
Yet without the method of inward self-reproach,
Or the practice of restraining anger and purifying desire,
Even if one resolves conflicts externally,
One cannot release them from the unseen depths—
How could one then remain pure and dust-free,
Free and joyful in oneself,
And return to the original virtue of Heaven and Earth?

Thus, *"To reconcile great grievances will surely leave lingering grievances—
How then can it be called virtue?"*

Only the Sage governs the self and interacts with others,
In dealing with oneself and awaiting others,
Always prioritizing self-cultivation,
And never concerning oneself with others’ judgments or preferences.
Like sealing a contract,
Dividing left and right to hold it—
Forever relying on it,
And making clear the intention:
*"No fear of you deceiving me,
No fear of I deceiving you."*

The Sage holds *virtue/power* as one holds the left contract,
Only cultivating within oneself and never blaming others—
This is why they align with Heaven and Earth in their greatness.

This is called *"The virtuous govern contracts."*
The unvirtuous, however,
Place weight on the external and slight the internal,
Often regard scrutiny as clarity,
And must account for others’ enmities—
This is *"The unvirtuous govern disputes."*

Those who *"govern disputes"*,
Take fault-finding as their task,
Never reflect inwardly yet the people do not follow—
How can they compare with those who *"govern contracts"*,
Who blame themselves heavily and others lightly,
And thus all are trusting and faithful!

It is known that blaming others
Is to slight oneself—
One’s own virtue cannot be complete;
Blaming oneself
Is to slight others—
One’s own virtue is truly achieved.

If one does good to others,
Heaven’s favor will attend—
For endless ages without fail.

*The Classic of Documents* says:
*"The August Heaven has no favorites,
It aids only virtue"—
Is this not the same as *The Supreme Dao*’s saying:
*"Heaven’s Dao has no favorites,
Yet always favors the virtuous?"*

The Sage’s learning,
Is to wash the heart and retreat into secrecy.
Regarding outward virtues and vices,
Right and wrong, compliance or defiance—
All are not considered.
Thus, one filters thoughts and sinks into reflection,
Concentrates the spirit and silently observes,
Until the heart is clear and nature revealed,
Desires purified and principles refined—
Above, aligning with Heaven in virtue,
Through endless ages without erosion.

Its foundation begins with *guarding the center*,
Its completion lies in *embryonic breathing*—
Do you know of this within?

The ancients spoke of *embryonic breathing*—
Students must not mistake it for external breath or external *qi*.
It is when ordinary breath ceases,
And the true *yin* and true *yang* of the *dantian*,
The original spirit and original *qi*,
Fuse into one cluster,
Mixing into one breath—
*Yīnyīn yǔnyǔn* (vaporous and misty),
*Péngpéng bó bó* (vigorous and flourishing),
Opening and closing like gates,
Having and not having like a phantom.
Visible yet unseen,
Audible yet unheard—
Imagined yet with traces,
Faintly perceived yet with form.
This is perhaps the original breath of life.

The heart attains it and has substance,
The nature attains it and has function—
Without this breath, one cannot live.
To become a Sage of the highest rank,
One cannot be without this breath as its master.

The ancients said:
*"At the beginning of life,
The foundation is *li* (principle), giving rise to breath,
The breath giving rise to form—
This is the natural sequence of Heaven and Earth in generating life."*
